title-group.article-title: Long-Term Pulmonary Effects of Intrauterine Exposure to Endotoxin Following Preterm Birth in Sheep

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Anatomy & Developmental Biology, Monash University, Clayton, Australia
2Sansom Institute for Health Research and School of Pharmacy & Medical Sciences, University of South Australia, Adelaide, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Robert De Matteo, Department of Anatomy & Developmental Biology, Monash University, Clayton, VIC 3800, Australia Email: robert.dematteo@monash.edu

abstract.p: Our aim was to determine whether fetal exposure to intraamniotic lipopolysaccharide (LPS) persistently alters the lungs following moderate preterm birth. Fetal sheep were exposed to LPS (1 mg/d) or saline from 0.75 to preterm birth at 0.90 of gestation. Eleven weeks after preterm birth, lung structure was unaltered. Interleukin (IL)-1β messenger RNA (mRNA) levels were elevated in lungs of LPS-exposed lambs (P < .05) but IL-1β protein levels were unaltered. Lung mRNA levels of IL-6, IL-8 and tumor necrosis factor α, and percentage of inflammatory cells were not different between groups. Surfactant protein (SP)-A and SP-C mRNA levels and SP-B tissue protein expression were higher in LPS-exposed lambs than controls (all P < .05); however, expression of SP-A and SP-C proteins was reduced. Prenatal LPS exposure causes a persistent increase in gene expression of proinflammatory mediators and surfactant proteins and a decrease in lung tissue SP-A and -C protein expression after preterm birth, which may affect lung immunity.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Intrauterine infection or inflammation, including chorioamnionitis, is present in up to 60% of pregnancies that result in preterm birth and these factors are considered to play a major role in the etiology of preterm birth. 1,2 In such pregnancies, the fetus is chronically exposed to inflammatory mediators that are now recognized as being able to affect the development of multiple fetal organs. 3 As a result, exposure to intrauterine inflammation could have long-term consequences for health and disease. 4 The developing lung is known to be susceptible to intrauterine infection/inflammation, although the long-term pulmonary outcomes and underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. It is apparent that functional lung maturity may be enhanced soon after exposure to an inflammatory intrauterine environment, 5,6 which could explain the reduced incidence of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants exposed to chorioamnionitis. 7,8 This effect is thought to be mediated by an increased production of pulmonary surfactant, which results in increased lung compliance. 9,10 Although intrauterine inflammation can enhance lung function in preterm infants in the short-term, it has been shown to increase the risk of developing bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) 7,11,12 ; however, some recent studies show no such relationship. 13
–16 Experimental evidence suggests that prenatal inflammation could alter lung architecture by inhibiting alveolarization, thereby predisposing infants to BPD and later respiratory illness. 17,18

Previous studies on the effects of intrauterine inflammation on fetal lung architecture and postnatal lung function have produced conflicting results. In preterm fetal sheep, intrauterine exposure to endotoxin has been shown to impair alveolarization, resulting in fewer and larger alveoli. 17 In addition, pulmonary microvascular development 19 and pulmonary elastin deposition are affected by fetal endotoxin exposure. 20 In contrast, prolonged intrauterine exposure to endotoxin did not affect lung morphometry in near-term fetal sheep, 19 suggesting that recovery of normal structure had occurred.

Few studies have examined the lungs of postnatal animals following intrauterine lipopolysaccharide (LPS) exposure. Although alveolar simplification was seen at 0.86 of ovine gestation after LPS exposure, 17 no changes in lung structure were observed 2 months after spontaneous term birth following the same prenatal endotoxin exposure at 0.82 of term. 21 In contrast, in rats, offspring aged up to 60 days had fewer and larger alveoli following intraamniotic administration of LPS in late gestation 22 ; however, the growth of the rat pups exposed to LPS was lower than that of controls.

Although some studies have examined the long-term effects of intrauterine inflammation on lung development following birth at term, 21,22 few, if any, studies have been conducted following preterm birth. The pulmonary outcomes are likely to be different after preterm birth as the lung is required to function at an earlier stage of development. Although most infants exposed to intrauterine infection or inflammation, are born before term, the long-term postnatal effects of prenatal exposure to inflammation on lung development following preterm birth remain unclear. Owing to uncertainties as to the long-term, postnatal, effects of intrauterine inflammation on the developing lung our objective was to determine whether alterations in lung structure, surfactant production, and inflammatory status that have been observed in the endotoxin-exposed fetus persist into postnatal life following preterm birth. We continuously exposed fetal sheep to endotoxin (Escherichia coli) during the saccular and early alveolar periods of lung development, which is when intrauterine infection is likely in most cases of preterm birth. We induced moderately preterm birth of lambs at the minimum gestational age for viability without the requirement of intensive care; the equivalent gestational age in humans is approximately 32 to 34 weeks of gestation. Our study is important as even late preterm birth increases the risk of illness, including respiratory distress, infection, feeding problems, cerebral palsy, and cognitive impairment. 23 –25 We examined the lungs at 11 weeks after birth, which can be regarded as analogous to childhood in humans.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: All animal procedures were approved by the Monash University Animal Ethics Committee. We used 6 lambs prenatally exposed to endotoxin and 9 control lambs that were not exposed; all lambs were born approximately 14 days before term. The LPS-exposed lambs were singletons apart from 2 twins from the same pregnancy; the controls were singletons apart from 1 twin. To prepare for intrauterine LPS or saline exposure, date-mated pregnant Merino × Border Leicester ewes underwent aseptic surgery at approximately 110 days of gestational age (DGA; term is ∼147 days) for the chronic implantation of 2 osmotic mini-pumps (Alzet, 2.5 µL/h for 28 days) into the amniotic sac; the pumps were attached to the fetal hind limbs. The pumps contained either LPS (80 mg dissolved in saline; E coli, 055:B55, Sigma Chemical, St Louis, Missouri), which would deliver LPS into the amniotic fluid at 1 mg/d from the time of pump implantation, 19,26 or they contained saline for control fetuses. Ampicillin sodium (1 g/5 mL dissolved in saline, intramuscularly [i.m.]) was administered to all ewes for 3 days after surgery. To monitor fetal well-being, fetal arterial blood (0.3 mL) was sampled at regular intervals after surgery until induction of preterm birth.

sec.title: Induction of Moderate Preterm Birth
sec.p: In all animals, we induced birth at approximately 14 days before term (0.9 of term) as described previously. 27 Briefly, preterm labor and delivery were induced by administration of epostane (50 mg, intravenous [i.v.]; 2a, 4a, 17-4,5-epoxy-17-hydroxy-4,17-dimethyl-3-ketoandrostane-2-carbonitrile, Sanofi-Synthlabo), a competitive inhibitor of 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, which prevents the conversion of pregnenolone to progesterone. Betamethasone (5.7 mg, i.m.; Celestone Chronodose, Schering-Plough, Australia) was administered to ewes on 131 days of gestation, 6 hours preceding epostane administration, to facilitate the survival of preterm lambs.

sec.title: Management of Newborn Preterm Lambs
sec.p: Lambs were kept close to the ewe for the next 2 to 3 days. During this time, they were fed every 4 to 6 hours, primarily with milk expressed from the ewe; if ewe’s milk was unavailable, they were fed formula based on cow’s milk. At each feed, the lamb was weighed and rectal temperature recorded. After 24 hours, the lamb was encouraged to feed from the ewe. Approximately 2 to 3 days after birth, when the lamb was able to stand unsupported and its eyes were fully opened, it was allowed free access to its mother. All lambs were reared with their mothers until necropsy.

After birth, lambs were weighed weekly and CRL, TG, and FLL were measured. At 9 weeks after birth, lambs underwent surgery for implantation of femoral arterial and venous catheters. At 10 weeks after birth, the femoral arterial catheter was connected to a pressure transducer (DTX plus transducer, Becton Dickinson, Singapore), the output from which was digitally recorded (PowerLab8/30, ADInstruments Pty Ltd, Australia) using Chart for Windows software (version 5.01, ADInstruments Pty Ltd). Arterial pressure and heart rate (HR) were recorded for 2 hours on 2 consecutive days while the lambs lay prone in a sling. The digitized data were subsequently analyzed over 3-minute periods at 15-minute intervals to obtain systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressures (MAPs). Heart rate was derived from the arterial pressure waveform. Arterial blood was collected for blood gas analysis (Radiometer, Denmark).

sec.title: Necropsy and Tissue Collection
sec.p: At 11 weeks after birth, lambs were weighed and their dimensions were measured; they were then euthanized by an overdose of sodium pentobarbitone (325 mg/mL, i.v.). The lungs were removed and weighed. The left bronchus was ligated, and the left and right lungs were separated. Small portions of the left lung (avoiding major airways and blood vessels) were snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80°C for molecular analysis. The right lung was fixed via the trachea using 4% paraformaldehyde (in 0.1 mol/L phosphate buffer, pH 7.4) at a distending pressure of 20 cm H2O. Sections were then processed and paraffin-embedded for light microscopy analyses. Other major organs including the brain, heart, liver, spleen, kidneys, and adrenal glands were collected and weighed.

sec.title: Analysis of DNA and Protein Concentrations
sec.p: Pulmonary DNA concentrations and soluble protein concentrations were determined using an established fluorometric DNA assay and a standard colorimetric protein assay (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA, USA), respectively. 28,29 The DNA standards were prepared using salmon testes DNA (Sigma) diluted in sodium phosphate buffer (3 mol/L NaCl, 0.05 mol/L Na2HPO4, 0.05 mol/L NaH2PO4·2H2O, 0.002 mol/L EDTA, and pH 7.4) to achieve concentrations of 90, 45, 22.5, 11.25, 5.63, and 0 μg/mL. Protein standards were prepared using bovine serum albumin (A-7888, Sigma) diluted in distilled water to achieve concentrations of 90, 45, 22.5, 11.25, 5.63, and 0 μg/mL.

sec.title: Histological Analysis of Lung Tissue
sec.p: Sections (5 μm thick) were stained and then examined using a light microscope. Color images were captured using a digital camera linked to image analysis software (Image Pro Plus, version 6.0). All measurements were made on coded slides by the same observer (AA) who was blinded to the experimental groups. For each morphometric parameter, we obtained data from a total of 15 randomly chosen bronchioles for the airway wall analysis and 15 randomly chosen fields of view for the lung parenchyma analysis. These 15 randomly chosen airways or fields of view were chosen from 3 randomly selected tissue sections from each animal; these included at least 1 section from the upper, middle, and lower lobes of the lung.

sec.title: Morphometric analysis
sec.p: Paraffin-embedded sections of lung tissue were stained with Masson Trichrome stain. Measurements were made by superimposing test grids over projected images of the lung. Tissue and air-space fractions and mean linear intercept, the average distance between alveolar walls (Lm), were determined by point-counting methods. 30,31 Analyses were performed at a final magnification of ×200.

sec.title: Elastin and collagen analysis
sec.p: Paraffin-embedded sections were stained for elastin using the Hart resorcin-fuchsin stain and counterstained with tartrazine (0.25%) in saturated picric acid. For the collagen analysis, paraffin-embedded sections were stained using the Gordon and Sweet reticular fiber stain, which stains collagen types I and III; the sections were counterstained with eosin. Analyses were performed at a final magnification of ×1000. For each field of view, the area of tissue stained for either elastin or collagen was expressed as a percentage of the total area of tissue. This was then averaged for each animal and each experimental group.

sec.title: Analysis of bronchiolar wall structure
sec.p: Sections of lung tissue were scanned at a magnification of ×400, and all noncartilaginous airways that appeared in a near-circular cross section were included in the analysis; the approximate diameter of the airways analyzed ranged from 70 to 320 µm. The airways analyzed were considered to be terminal bronchioles; their generation number cannot be determined as they are too small to be dissected from lung tissue. Using light microscopy and image analysis software (Image Pro Plus, version 6.0), we measured the luminal area, the perimeter of the basement membrane (Pbm), the area of airway epithelium, the area of collagen in the outer airway wall, the area of airway smooth muscle (ASM), and the number of alveolar attachments. 32

sec.title: Perimeter of the basement membrane
sec.p: The Pbm was used as an index of airway size, and measurements of airway wall components were normalized by dividing by the Pbm. The Pbm has been shown to be a suitable marker of airway dimension because it does not change significantly with changes in lung volume or bronchoconstriction. 33

sec.title: Area of epithelium
sec.p: The area of the epithelium was calculated as the difference between the area enclosed by the epithelial basement membrane and the area of the lumen.

sec.title: Area of airway collagen
sec.p: Sections stained with Gordon and Sweet reticular fiber stain were used in the measurement of type I and type III collagens in the outer airway wall. The area of collagen was expressed relative to Pbm.

sec.title: Area of ASM
sec.p: To assess the area of ASM, we incubated lung tissue sections with a specific antibody against α-smooth muscle actin (SMA; anti-α-SMA, 1:500; M0851, DakoCytomation, Denmark) using an immunohistochemistry kit (En-Vision + Dual Link System-HRP [DAB+]), following antigen retrieval (0.01 mol/L Tris, 0.001 mol/L EDTA, pH 9; 20 minutes in microwave on high); sections were counterstained with hematoxylin. Specific staining of the primary antibody was confirmed using a negative control slide which contained no primary antibody. The ASM area in the outer airway wall was expressed relative to Pbm.

sec.title: Alveolar attachments
sec.p: These are the points where alveolar walls are radially attached to the outer wall of the airways; they were quantified as the number of attachment points around the margin of bronchioles in relation to the Pbm.

sec.title: Gene Expression Analysis
sec.p: Interleukin (IL)-1β, IL-6, IL-8 and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α-messenger RNA (mRNA) levels and surfactant protein (SP)-A, -B, -C, and -D in lung tissue were measured using quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qPCR), as described previously. 34 Primers to amplify each gene were designed on the basis of ovine sequences (Table 1). Primers for the amplification of the housekeeping gene ribosomal protein S29 (RPS29; Table 1) were used to account for minor differences in sample preparation between animals.

fn.p: a The nucleotide sequences for each forward and reverse primer (5′-3′) used to amplify each gene of interest. Primer sequences were designed based on the nucleotide sequence that corresponds to the listed Genbank accession number. The annealing temperature (Tm) and template cDNA concentrations used for the amplification of each gene are shown; for the housekeeping gene RPS29, the Tm and cDNA concentration used was the same as that of the gene of interest.

sec.p: Total RNA was extracted, DNase-treated (Qiagen, Australia), and reverse transcribed into complementary DNA ([cDNA] M-MLV Reverse Transcriptase, RNase H Minus, Point Mutant Kit; Promega, Madison, WI, USA). Qualitative PCR was performed using a Stratagene Mx3000P (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA) detection system using reactions that contained cDNA template, forward and reverse primers (Table 1), SYBR green (Platinum SYBR Green qPCR SuperMix-UDG; Invitrogen Life Technologies), and nuclease-free water. The thermal profile used to amplify the PCR products included an initial 2-minute incubation at 95°C, followed by 50 cycles of denaturation at 95°C for 3 seconds, annealing at 58/59/60°C (depending on the primers for each gene; see Table 1) for 20 seconds, and elongation at 72°C for 20 seconds. The fluorescence readings were recorded after each 72°C step. Dissociation curves were performed after each PCR run to ensure that a single PCR product had been amplified per primer set. Each sample was measured in triplicate, and a control sample, containing no template, was included in each run. The relative mRNA levels of each gene for each animal were normalized to the RPS29 mRNA values for that animal, using the ▵▵Ct method (where Ct is cycle threshold), and expressed relative to the mean gene mRNA levels in control fetuses.

sec.title: Protein extraction
sec.p: Total protein was extracted from lung tissue by homogenization in RIPA buffer (1× phosphate-buffered saline [PBS] pH 7.4, 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.1% sodium dodecyl sulfate [SDS], 0.5% sodium deoxycholate, and 1 “mini” complete protease inhibitor tablet per 10 mL [Roche Diagnostics]). The homogenate was then incubated on ice for 10 minutes and centrifuged at 16 000g for 20 minutes at 4°C. The supernatant was retained and protein concentrations were determined using the Bradford assay. 35

sec.title: Protein expression
sec.p: Total lung proteins (35 µg) were separated by SDS-polyacrylamide gel (PAGE 12.5%) under reducing conditions, and then transferred onto polyvinylidene fluoride ([PVDF] membranes (Millipore, Billerica, MA, USA). Membranes were incubated for 1 hour in block buffer (PBST; 5% skim milk powder in PBS containing 0.1% Tween 20). After blocking, membranes were incubated with primary antibody (rabbit anti-sheep IL-1β polyclonal antibody, 1:10 000; AHP423, AbD Serotec, Oxford, UK) overnight at 4°C. After washing with PBST, membranes were incubated for 1 hour with secondary antibody (horse radish peroxidase (HRP)-linked donkey anti-rabbit IgG, 1:15 000; GE Healthcare, Bucks, UK). Membranes were then washed with PBST, and immunoreactive bands were detected using Luminata Crescendo HRP substrate (Millipore). To standardize for protein loading, membranes were also incubated with rabbit anti-actin polyclonal antibody (1:5000; A2066, Sigma-Aldrich, St Loius, MO). The signal was detected using x-ray film, and densitometry analysis performed using ImageQuant TL analysis software (GE Healthcare, Waukesha, WI, USA).

sec.title: Protein extraction
sec.p: Total protein was extracted from lung tissue of control lambs (n = 7) and LPS-exposed lambs (n = 6) with minor modifications to a published method. 36 Briefly, 100 mg of lung tissue was homogenized in 1 mL of homogenization buffer (0.1 mol/L potassium phosphate buffer, containing 5 µL of complete protease inhibitor cocktail; Sigma-Aldrich). The homogenate was centrifuged at 500g for 5 minutes at 4°C to pellet cell debris. The supernatant was retained, protein concentrations were determined by bicinchoninic acid protein assay (Pierce, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Rockford, Illinois) and aliquots were frozen at −80°C until analysis.

sec.title: Protein expression
sec.p: Total lung protein (50 µg) was analyzed as previously described, 36 but with the following modifications. Gels were transferred to pSQ-PVDF (0.2 µm) for SP-B and SP-C analyses and to nitrocellulose for SP-A analysis with a semidry blotter (BioRad Laboratories, Hercules, California). After blocking, membranes were incubated overnight at 4°C with the following primary antibodies and dilutions: rabbit anti-human SP-A polyclonal antibody (1:2000, Chemicon International, Massachusetts); mouse anti-human SP-B monoclonal antibody (1:1000, produced by Dr Y. Suzuki, Kyoto University, Japan and kindly donated by F. Possmayer, University of Western Ontario, Canada); and rabbit anti-human recombinant SP-C polyclonal antibody (1:1000; Seven Hills Bioreagents, Cincinnati, Ohio). Membranes were probed with a commercial chemiluminescent agent (Amersham ECL Plus, GE Healthcare) for approximately 30 seconds and immunoreactive bands were visualized with ImageQuant LAS 4000 imager (GE Healthcare). Densitometric analysis was performed using ImageQuant TL software (Amersham Biosciences).

sec.title: Inflammatory Cell Analysis
sec.p: To assess the proportion of inflammatory cells within lung tissue, paraffin-embedded sections were immunohistochemically stained with an antibody against CD45 (mouse anti-sheep CD45 monoclonal antibody, 1:50; MCA2220, AbD Serotec). CD45, also known as common leukocyte antigen, is expressed on hematopoietic cells except erythrocytes and platelets; therefore, it is commonly used as an inflammatory cell marker. Sections underwent antigen retrieval (0.01 mol/L sodium citrate, pH 6; 20 minutes in microwave oven on high setting), and endogenous peroxidases were blocked with 3% hydrogen peroxide for 30 minutes. Nonspecific binding was blocked with 10% normal horse serum/0.1% bovine serum albumin/0.05 mol/L Tris-HCl pH 7.2 for 30 minutes prior to incubation with the primary antibody. CD45 was visualized using a labeled polymer-HRP (DakoCytomation) and 3,3′-diaminobenzidine. Sections were counterstained with hematoxylin. Specific staining of the primary antibody was confirmed using a negative control slide, which contained no primary antibody.

Analyses were performed at a final magnification of ×1000. Measurements were made on coded slides by the same observer (FS) who was “blinded” to the experimental groups. For each animal, the number of cells stained positive for CD45 was counted and expressed as a percentage of the total number of cells. This was then averaged for each experimental group.

sec.title: Statistical Analyses
sec.p: Data on postnatal growth were analyzed using a one-way repeated measures analysis of variance (ANOVA), with treatment and age as factors. Birth, necropsy, and cardiovascular data were analyzed using the Student unpaired t test. Lung parenchyma and airway wall parameters and proportions of inflammatory cells were analyzed using a nested ANOVA design, which included treatment, lung lobe, and field of view as factors. Protein and gene (first normalized by log 10 transformation) expression data were analyzed by the Student unpaired t test to compare mean values for control and LPS groups. P < .05 was considered to be statistically significant.

sec.title: Physiologic Data
sec.p: The mean gestational age at birth was similar in the LPS (133 ± 1 days) and control (133 ± 0 days) lambs (Table 2). Birth weight, postnatal growth, and body dimensions were similar in the 2 groups (Figure 1, Table 2). The survival rate of postnatal lambs exposed to LPS was 60% (6 of 10). There was no significant difference between groups in MAP at 10 weeks postnatal age; values in LPS-exposed and control lambs were 75 ± 2 and 78 ± 2 mm Hg, respectively; HR was also similar between the LPS (120 ± 6 bpm) and control (109 ± 9 bpm) lambs. Arterial blood gases were not different between the groups at 8 weeks postnatal age; mean values for all animals were PO2 98.0 ± 2.3 mm Hg, PCO2 38.2 ± 2.2 mm Hg, and pH 7.46 ± 0.02.

caption.p: Age-related changes in body weight from birth until 10 weeks postnatal age in control (open squares) and lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-exposed (solid circles) lambs. Fetal sheep were exposed to intraamniotic LPS (1 mg/day, n = 6) or saline (n = 9) from 110 days of gestational age (DGA) until induced preterm birth at ∼133 DGA (term ∼147 days). Data are presented as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM).

fn.p: Abbreviations: LPS, lipopolysaccharide; PN, postnatal age; CRL, crown-to-rump length; TG, thoracic girth; FLL, forelimb length; PI, ponderal index (body weight/CRL3); SEM, standard error of the mean.

a Fetal sheep were exposed to intraamniotic LPS (1 mg/day, n = 6) or saline (n = 9) from 110 days of gestational age (DGA) until induced preterm birth approximately 2 weeks before term. Values are mean ± SEM. No significant differences between treatment groups were observed.

sec.title: Necropsy Data
sec.p: The spleens of LPS lambs (51.2 ± 8.3 g) were significantly lighter than those of controls (83.5 ± 11.5 g); when adjusted for body weight the spleens of LPS lambs were 42% lighter than in controls (Table 3). The total kidney weight of LPS lambs, when adjusted for body weight, was significantly lower, by 12%, than that of controls (Table 3). Lung weight, either dry or wet, or when adjusted for body weight, was similar in LPS and control lambs (Table 4).

caption.p: Organ Weights of Control and LPS-Exposed Lambs at Necropsy (11 Weeks Postnatal Age)a

fn.p: Abbreviations: LPS, lipopolysaccharide; SEM, standard error of the mean; BW, body weight.
a Organ weights are expressed as absolute weights and are also adjusted for BW. Data are presented as mean ± SEM.
b P < .05, LPS-exposed compared with control lambs.

caption.p: Lung Weight and Structure in Control and LPS-Exposed Lambs at 11 Weeks Postnatal Agea

fn.p: Abbreviations: LPS, lipopolysaccharide; wt, weight; BW, body weight; Naa, number of alveolar attachments; SEM, standard error of the mean.
a Data are presented as mean ± SEM.

sec.title: Lung DNA and Protein Content
sec.p: There was no significant difference in the lung DNA concentration or total lung DNA content (both absolute and relative to body weight), between the control and LPS-exposed lambs (Table 4). The protein concentration and total protein content of lung tissue (both absolute and relative to body weight) were also not different between the treatment groups (Table 4).

sec.title: Lung Parenchyma
sec.p: The percentages of tissue space, air space, collagen and elastin, and the mean linear intercept were similar between groups (Table 4).

sec.title: Bronchiolar Wall Structure
sec.p: There was no significant difference in Pbm between LPS (668.8 ± 15.6 µm) and control (665.6 ± 12.9 µm) lambs (Table 4). The Pbm in the LPS group ranged from 454 to 935 µm, and in the controls it ranged from 378 to 903 µm. The bronchiolar epithelial area of LPS lambs (8.33 ± 0.68 µm2/µm) tended to be greater than that of controls (7.58 ± 0.47 µm2/µm; P = .08). The number of alveolar attachment sites surrounding the bronchioles, and the amounts of collagen and α-SMA in the outer airway wall were similar between groups (Table 4).

sec.title: Cytokines and Inflammatory Cells
sec.p: In lung tissue, the relative gene expression of IL-1β was significantly higher in LPS lambs than in controls, whereas gene expression of IL-6, IL-8, and TNF-α was not significantly different between groups (Figure 2). There was no difference in the protein expression of IL-1β between the groups (Figure 3A). There was also no difference in the percentage of CD45 positive cells in the lung tissue of LPS-exposed lambs compared with controls (Figure 3B).

caption.p: Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) gene expression analysis of proinflammatory cytokines in control (open bars) and lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-exposed (closed bars) preterm lambs at 11 weeks postnatal age. The gene expression of (A) interleukin (IL)-1β, (B) IL-6, (C) IL-8 and (D) tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α. Data are presented as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). *P < .05.

(A) Pulmonary interleukin (IL)-1β protein expression and (B) percentage of CD45 positive cells in control (open bars) and lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-exposed (closed bars) preterm lambs at 11 weeks postnatal age. Data are presented as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM).

sec.title: Surfactant Protein mRNA and Protein
sec.p: In LPS lambs, SP-A and SP-C mRNA levels were significantly higher than in controls; SP-B and SP-D expression was not different between groups (Figure 4). In the lungs of LPS lambs, tissue protein expression of SP-A and SP-C was significantly lower than in control lambs, whereas the expression of SP-B protein was higher than that of controls (Figure 5).

caption.p: Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) gene expression analysis of pulmonary surfactant proteins (SP)-A, -B, -C, and -D in control (open bars) and lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-exposed (closed bars) preterm lambs at 11 weeks postnatal age. Data are presented as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). *P < .05.

Pulmonary surfactant protein (SP) protein expression analysis of SP-A, -B, and -C in control (open bars) and lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-exposed (closed bars) preterm lambs at 11 weeks postnatal age. Data are presented as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). *P < .05.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We have shown, for the first time, that prolonged fetal exposure to an inflammatory intrauterine environment has persistent effects on the lungs following preterm birth, in the absence of differences in body growth. In the postnatal lungs, we found evidence of increased gene expression of surfactant proteins and an altered tissue protein expression of these surfactant proteins in association with a persistent elevation of proinflammatory cytokine gene expression. We therefore suggest that an altered immune gene expression profile may be responsible for the altered SP expression as reported previously in the fetal lung. 9,37,38 At 11 weeks after birth, we found no evidence of structural alterations in the lung parenchyma following intraamniotic LPS exposure; we also found no overt effects on the bronchiolar walls. Surprisingly, LPS exposure reduced kidney and spleen weights in relation to body weight.

sec.title: Lung Structure
sec.p: Previous studies examining the effects of intrauterine inflammation on fetal lung development have provided conflicting data. Administration of LPS (20 mg) into the ovine amniotic sac at 119 DGA led to an increase in alveolar volume and a reduction in alveolar number 6 days later. 17 A reduction in alveolarization (ie, fewer and larger alveoli) was also seen at 125 DGA following LPS infusion (0.6 mg/d) from 80 to 108 DGA. 37 Following 28 days of intrauterine LPS (1 mg/d) exposure in sheep, which started at 80 DGA, Kallapur et al 19 assessed fetal lung structure at both 110 DGA and 138 DGA. At 110 DGA, they found a reduced number of (pre-alveolar) saccules, but at 138 DGA (ie, 30 days after the cessation of LPS administration), they found no differences in lung structure. In another study of the long-term effects of intrauterine LPS (20 mg at 119 DGA) exposure in sheep, Moss et al 21 found no differences in lung structure or lung function in 8-week-old lambs born at term. Taken together, the data from the present and previous studies in sheep suggest that alveolarization in the developing lung may be inhibited by an inflammatory environment soon after exposure, but the lung undergoes repair following LPS exposure, potentially by accelerated alveolarization in utero or soon after birth. The initial inhibition of alveolarization may arise as a result of perturbed septal elastin deposition which has been reported at 3 to 7 days after LPS exposure. 20

The inhibition of alveolarization by prenatal LPS exposure is supported by data from rats; however, unlike sheep, the effects persist after birth. Ueda et al 22 found that late gestational exposure to LPS in rats, via maternal IP injection during the saccular stage of lung development, resulted in reduced alveolarization which was still evident at 60 days after birth; however, the postnatal growth of the rat pups exposed to endotoxin was lower than that of controls and restricted growth on its own can impair lung development. 39 Similar findings have been reported by Zhan et al 40 in rats aged 7 and 14 days following intracervical LPS administration during the pseudoglandular stage of lung development. In another study using rats, maternal systemic exposure to LPS during pregnancy led to delayed alveolarization after birth, but the effect was absent 21 days after birth, suggestive of structural recovery as seen in our lambs. 41 The apparent differences between postnatal studies are likely due to species differences in the developmental timing of lung development, as well as differences in the level or timing of LPS exposure.

No previous studies have examined the effects of intrauterine inflammation on the conducting airways. It is likely that the airway epithelium would be exposed to intraamniotic LPS, as it has been shown that the effects of intraamniotic LPS on the alveolar epithelium are dependent upon access via the conducting airways. 10 The only evidence of a structural alteration in the airway walls was a trend for the bronchiolar epithelium to be thicker in LPS-exposed animals; it is possible that there may have been alterations in the airways at birth, and that wall structure had returned to normal by 11 weeks after birth.

sec.title: Pulmonary Inflammation
sec.p: An unexpected finding was the persistently elevated gene expression of IL-1β in the lungs of 11-week-old lambs exposed in utero to LPS, with similar but nonsignificant trends in IL-6, IL-8, and TNF-α. Interestingly, there was no increase in the tissue protein expression of IL-1β or the percentage of leukocytes in lung tissue, which may explain the absence of overt histological evidence of pulmonary inflammation. A previous study in which intraamniotic LPS was administered repeatedly throughout gestation in sheep, showed elevated leukocytes in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) at term; however, by 7 weeks after birth, the pulmonary inflammation was absent. 42 It is possible that there is a transient increase in pulmonary inflammation at birth, following intraamniotic LPS, which resolves soon after birth. Our finding of elevated gene expression of IL-1β is consistent with the elevated proinflammatory cytokine (IL-1β, IL-6, and CXCL1) mRNA expression and infiltration of neutrophils that were observed in the lungs of 14-day old rats after late gestational exposure to LPS. 41 This was associated with an attenuation of alveolarization, but by postnatal day 21, the difference from controls was no longer present. As the preterm fetal lung contains few macrophages or granulocytes, 43 an inflammatory insult would be expected to recruit neutrophils and monocytes into the lung. This inflammatory insult may permanently alter gene expression of proinflammatory cytokines that may attenuate alveolarization at birth; however, the pulmonary inflammation appears to resolve with time such that alveolarization becomes normal after birth. It would be interesting to test the pulmonary inflammatory system in adulthood as the prolonged inflammation, as produced in our study, could persistently alter the development of the immune system as seen in preterm infants exposed to chorioamnionitis. 44

It has been shown that gestational exposure to LPS in rats can lead to decreased Th2 cytokine levels (IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13) and increased Th1 cytokine levels (IL-2 and IFN-γ) in offspring at 14 days of postnatal age. 45 The Th1- and Th2-mediated responses are related to cell-mediated and antibody-mediated immunity, respectively. This altered balance of the Th1 and Th2 immune pathways might be partially responsible for the increased level of proinflammatory cytokines. Furthermore, there is evidence that IFN-γ, a Th1 cytokine, stimulates expression of surfactant protein production, whereas IL-13, a Th2 cytokine, suppresses SP production in adult human alveolar type 2 cells in vitro. 46 Taken together, it appears likely that such an alteration of Th1 and Th2 immune system balance may lead to increased expression of surfactant protein mRNA.

sec.title: Pulmonary Surfactant
sec.p: Several studies have examined the effects of intrauterine inflammation on pulmonary surfactant before birth. In sheep, gene expression of SP-A, -B, and -C was increased in fetal lung tissue following various routes of LPS administration, 9,37,47,48 which is in agreement with the findings of the present study. An increase in SP-A and -B protein has been reported in lung tissue 9 and an increase in SP-B protein has been reported in BALF 48 shortly after LPS exposure. In humans, an increase in SP-B concentration in amniotic fluid has also been reported in pregnancies with intraamniotic infection. 49 However, we are unaware of studies that have examined the persistence of these effects after term or preterm birth. Given an increase in SP-B mRNA, albeit nonsignificant, in conjunction with an increase in lung tissue SP-B protein, it is likely that alveolar SP-B (ie, SP-B secreted from lung tissue into the lung lumen) was increased in the present study. The apparently conflicting changes in lung tissue protein and gene expression levels of SP-A and -C seen in our study could arise from a relative increase in alveolar secretion rates, leading to a depletion in protein tissue stores. Alternatively, there may be a decrease in translation rates of mRNA or an accelerated degradation of SP mRNA, both of which would lead to a decrease in alveolar protein. As BALF was not collected, it is unclear whether alveolar SP-A and -C levels increase or decrease. However, taking into account the previous findings of the effect of LPS on pulmonary SP expression, 9,37,47,48 together with the findings in the present study of increased proinflammatory cytokine expression, it is likely that there was a general increase in the rate of surfactant turnover. The increase in SP-A mRNA is likely stimulated by the altered inflammatory state of the lung, as IL-1α and -β have both been shown to stimulate SP-A gene transcription in vitro. 50 However, it is also possible that the increased SP gene expression does not translate into increased protein expression, as increased inflammatory mediators, particularly IL-1 have also been shown to stimulate SP mRNA degradation in vitro. 51

Given the uncertainty of the changes in alveolar SP expression, the functional implications for the postnatal lung are unclear. If the levels of alveolar SP-B and -C increase then lung function is not likely to be adversely affected. Even if alveolar SP-B increases, but alveolar SP-C decreases, as observed with SP-B and -C tissue levels, lung function in the mature lung is unlikely to be affected, as the roles of these 2 hydrophobic proteins in promoting surfactant film formation and function are somewhat redundant. 52 Indeed, we observed no evidence of differences in respiratory function (as indicated by arterial blood gases) or cardiovascular function (as indicated by MAP and HR) between the treatment groups. Changes in the expression of the hydrophilic collectins, SP-A and -D, may lead to alterations in pulmonary innate immunity. 53 Regulation and function of these 2 proteins is complex, as they are able to elicit either a proinflammatory response, if needed, to combat infection or an anti-inflammatory response, if required, to limit inflammation and avoid tissue damage (reviewed by Orgeig et al54). Hence, in the present study, a potential increase in alveolar SP-A may be protective, serving to limit tissue damage due to the presence of elevated proinflammatory cytokines. On the other hand, a potential decrease in production of SP-A may have a detrimental effect on lung innate immunity in postnatal life, with a potential for increased risk of infection, inflammation, and airway sensitization. 55,56

sec.title: Kidney Development
sec.p: Surprisingly, we found that kidney weight, relative to body weight, was significantly reduced by 12% in the LPS-exposed animals compared with controls. This could be a result of reduced nephrogenesis, which has been observed in fetal sheep at 128 DGA following a single intraamniotic injection of LPS at 121 DGA. 57 It has been shown that chorioamnionitis is independently associated with an elevated risk of renal and electrolyte abnormalities, 58 suggestive of renal dysfunction. The period of LPS infusion in our study coincided with the known period of nephrogenesis in sheep, which ends at around 135 days of ovine gestation. 59,60 As nephrogenesis is completed in sheep during late gestation, as it is in humans, any nephron deficit is likely to be permanent. A reduction in the final complement of nephrons could increase the risk of renal disease later in life. 61,62

sec.title: Spleen
sec.p: The weight of the spleen, relative to body weight, was reduced by 42% in LPS-exposed lambs compared with controls. The cause of this apparent hyposplenia is unknown. A previous study has shown that chorioamnionitis in humans results in injury to the spleen, including shrinkage and depletion of B and T lymphocytes. 63 The subjects of that study were fetuses and neonates who died of severe inflammation, whereas our subjects were exposed to only mild to moderate inflammation which caused neither fetal death nor abortion; therefore, the mechanism may be quite different. Intrauterine inflammation alters the immune system of the neonate postnatally in that Th1 immunity is augmented and Th2 immunity is reduced. 41 The spleen is an important organ for antibody-mediated immunity, as it is the site of B-cell proliferation. Therefore, reduced activity of Th2 immunity could possibly diminish the proliferation of B cells leading to hyposplenia. Measuring serum immunoglobulin or the differential count of lymphocytes might provide evidence for this hypothesis. Hyposplenia may also be indicative of impaired red blood cell production in the fetus, but our LPS-exposed lambs had normal hematocrit and blood hemoglobin content (data not presented), so this is unlikely in our study.

sec.title: Study Limitations
sec.p: To ensure the survival of our preterm lambs without the need for ventilatory support, it was necessary to deliver a single, small dose of corticosteroid (5.7 mg) before birth. Previous studies in sheep have reported that the immune/inflammatory response can be altered by antenatal corticosteroid exposure. Maternal betamethasone administration (0.5 mg/kg maternal bodyweight; approximately 30 mg) initially suppressed cord blood monocyte function in vitro by reducing H2O2 and IL-6 production for 3 days after stimulation by LPS; however, after 7 days, monocyte function was found to be more proinflammatory. 64 Betamethasone administration (0.5 mg/kg maternal bodyweight) has also been shown to initially inhibit LPS-induced lung inflammation in the preterm lamb at 1 day; however, after 15 days, preterm lambs had increased lung inflammation compared with preterm lambs exposed to LPS alone. 65 Lung function has been shown to be improved with combined betamethasone and LPS administration, 65 compared with either agent alone. 66 Although we observed no changes in lung structure, which may be due to our use of lower levels of betamethasone and endotoxin exposure than in previous studies, it is possible that either betamethasone and/or LPS exposure may be responsible for the increased IL-1β gene expression that we observed at 11 weeks of age.

We were unable to provide direct evidence that our LPS-exposed fetuses were indeed exposed to intrauterine inflammation; however, we used the same LPS infusion protocol as a previous study in sheep in which histological and cytokine evidence of intrauterine inflammation was obtained. 19 Therefore, we are confident that our LPS-exposed lambs were exposed to an inflammatory intrauterine environment.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: We conclude that chronic intrauterine exposure to LPS during late gestation leads to increased pulmonary gene expression of IL-1β, SP-A, and SP-C, increased lung tissue protein expression of SP-B, and decreased lung tissue protein expression of SP-A and SP-C at 11 weeks after preterm birth. It is likely that these effects are causally linked, as is the case in the fetus. Intrauterine exposure to LPS also led to reductions in kidney and spleen growth that persisted to 11 weeks after birth, which could have adverse long-term effects on renal function and immune function, respectively.
